memberdef.name: detail_LogIfCategoryAndLevelEnabled
memberdef.initializer: do { \ if (LogAcceptCategory((category), (level))) { \ bool rate_limit{level >= BCLog::Level::Info}; \ Assume(!rate_limit);/*Only called with the levels below*/ \ LogPrintLevel_(category, level, rate_limit, __VA_ARGS__); \ } \ } while (0)

inbodydescription.para: NOTE: the logger instances is leaked on exit. This is ugly, but will be cleaned up by the OS/libc. Defining a logger as a global object doesn't work since the order of destruction of static/global objects is undefined. Consider if the logger gets destroyed, and then some later destructor calls LogInfo, maybe indirectly, and you get a core dump at shutdown trying to access the logger. When the shutdown sequence is fully audited and tested, explicit destruction of these objects can be implemented by changing this from a raw pointer to a std::unique_ptr. Since the ~Logger() destructor is never called, the Logger class and all its subclasses must have implicitly-defined destructors.
This method of initialization was originally introduced in ee3374234c60aba2cc4c5cd5cac1c0aefc2d817c.

detaileddescription.para: Return true if log accepts specified category, at the specified level.
Return true if str parses as a log category and set the flag

memberdef.argsstring: (SourceLocation &&source_loc, BCLog::LogFlags flag, BCLog::Level level, bool should_ratelimit, util::ConstevalFormatString< sizeof...(Args)> fmt, const Args &... args)
memberdef.name: LogPrintFormatInternal
